articles.title: NASA’s Hubble Reveals Largest Found Chaotic Birthplace of Planets
articles.summary: Astronomers using NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope have imaged the largest protoplanetary disk ever observed circling a young star. For the first time in visible light, Hubble has revealed the disk is unexpectedly chaotic and turbulent, with wisps of material stretching much farther above and below the disk than astronomers have seen in any similar system. […]
articles.content:
Astronomers using NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope have imaged the largest protoplanetary disk ever observed circling a young star. For the first time in visible light, Hubble has revealed the disk is unexpectedly chaotic and turbulent, with wisps of material stretching much farther above and below the disk than astronomers have seen in any similar system. Strangely, more extended filaments are only visible on one side of the disk. The findings, which published Tuesday in The Astrophysical Journal, mark a new milestone for Hubble and shed light on how planets may form in extreme environments, as NASA’s missions lead humanity’s exploration of the universe and our place in it.

Located roughly 1,000 light-years from Earth, IRAS 23077+6707, nicknamed “Dracula’s Chivito,” spans nearly 400 billion miles — 40 times the diameter of our solar system to the outer edge of the Kuiper Belt of cometary bodies. The disk obscures the young star within it, which scientists believe may be either a hot, massive star, or a pair of stars. And the enormous disk is not only the largest known planet-forming disk; it’s also shaping up to be one of the most unusual.

“The level of detail we’re seeing is rare in protoplanetary disk imaging, and these new Hubble images show that planet nurseries can be much more active and chaotic than we expected,” said lead author Kristina Monsch of the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian (CfA). “We’re seeing this disk nearly edge-on and its wispy upper layers and asymmetric features are especially striking. Both Hubble and NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope have glimpsed similar structures in other disks, but IRAS 23077+6707 provides us with an exceptional perspective — allowing us to trace its substructures in visible light at an unprecedented level of detail. This makes the system a unique, new laboratory for studying planet formation and the environments where it happens.”

The nickname “Dracula’s Chivito” playfully reflects the heritage of its researchers—one from Transylvania and another from Uruguay, where the national dish is a sandwich called a chivito. The edge-on disk resembles a hamburger, with a dark central lane flanked by glowing top and bottom layers of dust and gas.

This Hubble Space Telescope image shows the largest planet-forming disk ever observed around a young star. It spans nearly 400 billion miles — 40 times the diameter of our solar system. Image: NASA, ESA, STScI, Kristina Monsch (CfA); Image Processing: Joseph DePasquale (STScI)

Puzzling asymmetry

The impressive height of these features wasn’t the only thing that captured the attention of scientists. The new images revealed that vertically imposing filament-like features appear on just one side of the disk, while the other side appears to have a sharp edge and no visible filaments. This peculiar, lopsided structure suggests that dynamic processes, like the recent infall of dust and gas, or interactions with its surroundings, are shaping the disk.

“We were stunned to see how asymmetric this disk is,” said co-investigator Joshua Bennett Lovell, also an astronomer at the CfA. “Hubble has given us a front row seat to the chaotic processes that are shaping disks as they build new planets — processes that we don’t yet fully understand but can now study in a whole new way.”

All planetary systems form from disks of gas and dust encircling young stars. Over time, the gas accretes onto the star, and planets emerge from the remaining material. IRAS 23077+6707 may represent a scaled-up version of our early solar system, with a disk mass estimated at 10 to 30 times that of Jupiter — ample material for forming multiple gas giants. This, plus the new findings, makes it an exceptional case for studying the birth of planetary systems.

“In theory, IRAS 23077+6707 could host a vast planetary system,” said Monsch. “While planet formation may differ in such massive environments, the underlying processes are likely similar. Right now, we have more questions than answers, but these new images are a starting point for understanding how planets form over time and in different environments.”

Credit: NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center; Lead Producer: Paul Morris

The Hubble Space Telescope has been operating for over three decades and continues to make ground-breaking discoveries that shape our fundamental understanding of the universe. Hubble is a project of international cooperation between NASA and ESA (European Space Agency). NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, manages the telescope and mission operations. Lockheed Martin Space, based in Denver, also supports mission operations at Goddard. The Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, conducts Hubble science operations for NASA.

articles.personality_title: Hubble captures largest and most chaotic planet-forming disk ever seen
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study how planets form by looking at disks of gas and dust around young stars. These disks are called protoplanetary disks because planets are born from them.

**What happened** – Using NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope, astronomers took pictures of the biggest protoplanetary disk ever found. This disk, named IRAS 23077+6707 or “Dracula’s Chivito,” is about 1,000 light-years away and 40 times wider than our solar system. For the first time in visible light, the disk looks very messy and uneven, with wisps of dust and gas stretching high above and below it, but only on one side.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it shows that planet-forming disks can be more active and wild than scientists thought. The disk may hold enough material to form many large planets, helping us understand how giant planets could form in extreme places. The unusual shape and size give researchers a rare chance to study planet birth in detail.

**What’s next step** – Scientists will keep studying this disk to learn why it is so lopsided and how the dust and gas move around. They will also compare it to other disks seen by Hubble and NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope to better understand different ways planets form.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s Hubble has revealed the largest and most chaotic planet-forming disk ever seen, offering new clues about how planets come to life around young stars.
articles.personality_title_fr: Hubble capture le plus grand et chaotique disque formant des planètes jamais observé
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient la formation des planètes en observant des disques de gaz et de poussière autour des jeunes étoiles, appelés disques protoplanétaires.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Grâce au télescope spatial Hubble de la NASA, des astronomes ont photographié le plus grand disque protoplanétaire jamais découvert. Ce disque, nommé IRAS 23077+6707 ou « le Chivito de Dracula », se trouve à environ 1000 années-lumière et est 40 fois plus large que notre système solaire. Pour la première fois en lumière visible, le disque apparaît très chaotique et inégal, avec des filaments de poussière et de gaz s’étendant haut au-dessus et en dessous, mais seulement d’un côté.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle montre que les disques formant des planètes peuvent être plus actifs et désordonnés que prévu. Le disque contient assez de matière pour former plusieurs grosses planètes, ce qui aide à comprendre la naissance des géantes planétaires dans des environnements extrêmes. Sa forme et sa taille inhabituelles offrent une occasion rare d’étudier en détail la formation des planètes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont continuer à étudier ce disque pour comprendre pourquoi il est si asymétrique et comment la poussière et le gaz se déplacent. Ils le compareront aussi à d’autres disques observés par Hubble et le télescope spatial James Webb.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Hubble a révélé le plus grand et chaotique disque formant des planètes jamais vu, offrant de nouvelles pistes pour comprendre la naissance des planètes autour des jeunes étoiles.
articles.personality_title_es: Hubble captura el disco formador de planetas más grande y caótico jamás visto
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian cómo se forman los planetas observando discos de gas y polvo alrededor de estrellas jóvenes. Estos discos se llaman discos protoplanetarios porque de ellos nacen los planetas.

**Qué pasó** – Usando el telescopio espacial Hubble de la NASA, los astrónomos tomaron imágenes del disco protoplanetario más grande que se haya encontrado. Este disco, llamado IRAS 23077+6707 o “Chivito de Drácula,” está a unos 1,000 años luz y es 40 veces más ancho que nuestro sistema solar. Por primera vez en luz visible, el disco se ve muy desordenado y desigual, con mechones de polvo y gas que se extienden alto arriba y abajo, pero solo en un lado.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo es importante porque muestra que los discos donde nacen planetas pueden ser más activos y caóticos de lo que se pensaba. El disco podría tener suficiente material para formar muchos planetas grandes, ayudando a entender cómo se forman los gigantes planetarios en lugares extremos. Su forma y tamaño inusuales dan a los científicos una oportunidad única para estudiar la formación de planetas con mucho detalle.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán estudiando este disco para entender por qué es tan asimétrico y cómo se mueve el polvo y el gas. También lo compararán con otros discos observados por Hubble y el telescopio espacial James Webb para entender mejor las diferentes formas en que se forman los planetas.

**Frase clave** – Hubble ha revelado el disco formador de planetas más grande y caótico jamás visto, ofreciendo nuevas pistas sobre cómo nacen los planetas alrededor de estrellas jóvenes.
